While "Somalia, Through a Glass Darkly" (Op-Ed, Sept. 30) by George F. Kennan reflects the wisdom to be expected from an almost unique American foreign policy sage, and offers an eerily accurate description of the tragic United States morass in Mogadishu, it is, unfortunately, based on an erroneous and offensive premise that "the people of Somalia are wholly unable to govern themselves." Mr. Kennan also states that any resolution "could not be a democratic one, because the very prerequisites for a democratic political system do not exist among the people in question."

Somalia, long before its struggle for independence in 1960, was known to scholars as a pastoral democracy. There is probably no better example in Africa of an entire society accepting the judgments and unwritten rules of elected elders. That Somali democracy flourished during the first decade of independence and even survived the oppressive regime of Gen. Mohammed Siad Barre.

It is, in fact, that fundamental democratic structure of Somali society which must now be recognized and strengthened. We will not in any way succeed in imposing some new system of government on this proud and independent people, among whom I have worked for more than 30 years. KEVIN M. CAHILL, M.D. President and Director, Center for Intl. Health & Cooperation New York, Oct. 4, 1993
